para.tab:
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid)
took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer in respect of the administrative complexities of the government's new 15 per cent superannuation tax. Are you aware of the trenchant criticisms of: Professor David Knox, former Liberal superannuation adviser and currently member of the government's actuarial advisory committee; Mr Bruce Cook, chairman of William M. Mercer; Mr Brian Bissacker of Bankers Trust; Mr Emery Feyzeny of KPMG and your own Liberal Senate colleague Senator John Watson on the superannuation tax? When will you acknowledge the broad community concerns on this issue? Will you support referral to the Senate committee on superannuation with a report back date by 30 November?

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —The one thing that this question shows, quite clearly, is that the opposition is not prepared to join the government in seeking a fairer superannuation system for all Australians. That is the nub of what this question is all about. Is the Australian Labor Party really fair dinkum about supporting the surcharge that we have imposed in the budget? Mr Beazley says one thing and Senator Sherry says another thing. Someone says, `We will refer it to a committee.' Others say, `We do not need to do so—
—Madam President, on a point of order—
—He can't take it. He has absolutely bogged himself down.
—For the first time we would like an answer from Senator Short to a specific question. When will he answer this question?
—Chance your arm, you hopeless individual.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I simply draw attention to the fact that a fair degree of latitude is involved in points of order. But we have just had a naked example of a total disregard of the rules that had absolutely nothing to do with what preceded it. It was simply a cheap debating point. It can be made at any other time and it should not be made now—and you should not allow that sort of abuse of question time to continue.
—Senator Short has spoken for less than one minute to this point and has the opportunity to develop an answer.

—I preface my answer to Senator Sherry by asking the Labor Party, through you, whether it really does want greater fairness in the superannuation system in this country. If it does, then it would support the thrust of the policy decision.
—You are obligated to answer the question. Answer the question.
—You don't like hearing the truth, Senator Faulkner, because truth is a word that is pretty out of your vocabulary and always has been.

answer.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Short, just wait, please. It is impossible to hear with so much noise in the chamber.

—If Labor took the same starting point as us in wanting greater fairness and, therefore, really supporting the surcharge that we have proposed in the budget—which Senator Sherry, I think, and Mr Beazley have said they do support—then it would be logical to wait until the legislation is introduced into the parliament after the extensive consultations that are going on at the moment.

para.break: Senator Sherry well knows that an actuarial advisory committee is looking at these issues in relation to defined benefit funds and unfunded schemes. He knows that the government has established a task force which comprises representatives of the ISC, the ATO, Treasury and industry to look at these issues. He knows that extensive consultations are going on, including the involvement of Professor David Knox, and we are very pleased that he is doing that; he is approach ing it in a very constructive way. Consultations are going on.

answer.para: The logical, systematic, due process way to proceed with this would be to let those consultations proceed and, as a result, have the legislation drafted and presented to parliament. Then the parliament, through its committee systems, can have every opportunity to look at the legislation.

But, quite frankly, it is absolutely ridiculous to say before that legislation is drafted, before the consultations have concluded—we are only halfway through the consultations—`Let's go and look at all the fine detail of this issue' before you have the detail to consider. It casts very grave doubts on the real motives of the Labor Party on this issue.

talk.start.para: —A supplementary. Senator, you still refuse to acknowledge the broad community concerns.
—Put your question through the chair.
—I take it from your answer that you do not want this matter referred to the Senate committee. Therefore, do you agree with Senator John Watson—
—Senator Sherry, your question should be addressed through the chair.
—Do you agree with Senator John Watson's support on 11 September at a meeting of the Senate select committee in referring this matter to that committee?

—Could I take a point of order, Madam President? It is very sad that Senator Sherry, who has now been here for some years—he is apparently the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate—still does not understand the requirement that questions should be addressed through the chair. Now what that—
—I am doing that.
—But you don't! You were told three times that you ought to ask the question in the third person.
—You aren't addressing the chair!

—I am making my remarks through the chair. I am making the point that
Senator Sherry does not comprehend the difference between asking a question in the second person or the third person. That is what it is all about. He ought to know the distinction. Madam President, you should not allow him to continue in ignorance. If he is going to address questions through the chair, there is a proper form to be followed, and it is very unfortunate that after all these years he still has not got the vaguest idea.
—Order! Whenever the word `you' is used, it is apparent that the question or answer is not being directed through the chair. They should be. Have you completed your question, Senator Sherry?
—Yes, Madam President.

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the government is not saying that the details of the implementation complexities should not be considered at all by a committee. What we are saying—and we are really prejudging the debate that is to come up a little later—is that until the consultations have taken place, until legislation has been drafted and brought into this parliament so one can see the details, then it is premature to refer such a matter of administration to a committee.

answer.para: What are you going to do when the legislation comes in—by the end of the year, hopefully? Are you going to do it again and again and again? It is quite deliberate time wasting on the part of the Labor Party in an attempt, I think, to thwart the introduction of a major change to the superannuation system that will make superannuation fairer and more equitable for all Australians.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President. Through you, I ask the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron: Minister, in light of yesterday's announcement that the government plans to legislate to allow construction of the Hindmarsh Island bridge to proceed, can you outline the reasons why the government has taken this decision—

—Could I take a point of order, Madam President? Senator Ellison used the word `you' that you just ruled out—I
think very foolishly, Madam President. Will you rule him out?
—On the point of order, Madam President, if Senator Ray had listened, I prefaced my comment by `Through you, Madam President'—
—I know. Silly ruling.
—and I believe that distinguishes what Madam President has said, Senator Ray.
—No, it does not. In fact it does not, and twice previously I have called government ministers when answering questions on this point. It is the way in which you refer also to other people.

—Madam President, on the point of order: I think Senator Ellison's question is totally in order. The use of the word `you' to a minister has been used here ever since this chamber started. It is, I guess, when the questioner is only just looking at the minister, never referring to you, then you could take action. But, if you think about that ruling you have made, it is just not practical.
—It was an observation I made about the use of the word `you', and it frequently refers to the fact that somebody is not directing their remarks through the chair and referring to people personally.

—In light of yesterday's announcement that the government plans to legislate to allow the construction of the Hindmarsh Island bridge to continue, can the minister outline the reasons why the government has taken this decision, and can he detail to the Senate the costs involved since the previous Labor government first took action to stop work on the Hindmarsh Island bridge?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para:
—Thank you, Senator Ellison, for that question. The government has taken the view that, after complete bungling and incompetence by the previous government, this matter has gone on for long enough. The sad fact is that we have had four state and federal inquiries costing in excess of $3 million, the latest by Justice Jane Mathews costing over $1 million. In addition, it is estimated that well over $1 million has been spent on associated legal appeals and actions
in various courts. Of the four inquiries, three, Senator Ellison, have found that the bridge should go ahead, and the one that found the area should be protected was overturned on appeal.

answer.para: When the previous government boxed themselves into a corner and proceeded, over 2½ years, to pour millions of dollars of taxpayers' money into efforts to justify their original decision to oppose the bridge, and after the High Court overturned the latest inquiry by Justice Jane Mathews, I was faced with the prospect of having to order yet another inquiry and, at the end of that, we could well face further legal appeals. The fiasco has gone on far enough. You have made yourselves—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Herron.
—A point of order!
—the laughing stock of the Australian public, and we are not going to do that.
—Order! Senator Herron.

—Could I take a point of order, Madam President? My point of order is this: we have had a sanctimonious point of order from Senator Alston about comments being directed through the chair. I ask you to make a consistent ruling and rule that Senator Herron's comments then were out of order, and direct him to make his comments through the chair.

—Of course. I had called him to order before you stood up, Senator Faulkner. I had called `order' before you stood up. I agree with you entirely, and the remarks should not be addressed in that fashion.
—Madam President, this fiasco has gone on far enough.
—So don't repeat it!

—I will repeat it. The opposition have made themselves the laughing stock of the Australian public. We have inherited this mess from the Labor Party, and we plan to clean it up. We plan to do that by introducing legislation that will deal specifically and solely with Hindmarsh Island.

break.para: The Labor Party has two choices—either accept that they made a mess of this and support our legislation to clean that mess up, or reject the legislation which will force a fifth inquiry, perhaps costing another million dollars of taxpayers' money. And, if they do reject it, Madam President, I suggest that the Labor Party should put up the money for the next inquiry because the Australian public is not prepared to do it. Madam President, I suggest the Labor Party should put up the money. Or do we put it on the Beazley Bankcard? We would have yet another fiasco if it goes onto the Beazley bankcard because that is where it will have to come from because the Australian public is not prepared to do that.

talk.start.para: —Come on, eyes down.
—Order!
—Do senators opposite—well, they don't want to do a U‐turn—
—On a point of order, Madam President: I don't think that Senator Herron has been listening to your ruling because he is straying again. He is not addressing his remarks through the chair.
—Senator Herron, you should direct your remarks through the chair and not directly to opposition senators.

—Madam President, they are a bit touchy on the other side this morning because I think the facts are coming home to roost on them after years of dilly‐dallying with this issue. Now they want the taxpayer to fork out more money in relation to the folly that has been pursued over a number of years by the previous government. They are between a rock and a hard place and they ought to wake up to that. If they want another inquiry, the ALP should put up the money for that inquiry, rather than the Australian taxpayer.

question.block.title: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, through you, I address a question to Senator Parer representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Could the minister please inform the Senate of the cost,
purpose and benefits to the Australian community and small business of the recent trip to the Philippines by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Prosser? Through you, Madam President, could the minister also comment on the reports that the Philippines government was so upset by Mr Prosser's repeated failure to attend working sessions of the APEC small and medium enterprises ministerial meeting that it considered lodging a diplomatic protest, and that such action was averted only by the professionalism of the officers accompanying him?

—I am aware of the fact that my colleague Minister Prosser did attend the APEC meeting in the Philippines. I have no idea of the cost. It was an APEC meeting. I have no idea of the comments that have been made by Senator Cook. I will refer them to the minister and come back to him.

—Madam President, in view of that answer, as a supplementary, can the minister provide the Senate with full details of Minister Prosser's program, including details as to which conference sessions he actually attended and what other—
—If any—
—If any; what other meetings, if any, he attended; what was discussed at them; and the details of the cost of this trip?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. In view of the minister's statements that, industry wide, there will be many new jobs created in the telecommunications area despite the loss of jobs in Telstra over the next few years, can the minister provide concrete examples of job creation in this industry?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para:
—Yes, there are many examples. United Telecommunications, for example, which aims to be Australia's largest Telstra Mobilenet service provider, currently has a national operations centre with some 200 staff. They expect to increase that by 300 to 500 staff in the near future. The regional
pay TV company, Austar—which has been rolling out a combined wireless satellite and cable television network across regional New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia and the Northern Territory—has already established 23 wireless cable systems in larger regional centres and aims to expand that—
—Twenty‐three! Twenty‐three out of 22,000!

—Quite right. I am equally impressed by the fact that you are impressed too. It plans to expand that to 40 such systems by the end of next year. It has also introduced satellite TV coverage across regional New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and South Australia. This has meant 600 new jobs throughout regional Australia, with another 200 people to be employed before the end of this year. In these two companies alone, we have more than 1,000 new jobs.

answer.para: The high level of employment growth in the private telecommunications sector is reflected in the overall figures. The Telecommunications Industry Development Authority has published figures which show that the number of employees in the equipment suppliers and service provider sector of the industry alone has increased by just short of 20,000 in the two years from December 1993. That is up 30 per cent. Employment growth in the communications sector overall is phenomenal—35,000 new jobs since 1993. Of course, during that period Telstra was downsizing.

Telstra's own activities in cable roll‐out and service expansion are also creating new jobs and new businesses across Australia. Some 1,200 jobs were created in Queensland alone during 1994‐95. These examples are only a taste of what is to come. Paynet Telecommunications plans to roll out cable in Cairns and, hopefully, Townsville. Neighbourhood Cable plans to offer video on demand and other services to a regional community south‐east of Melbourne. Northgate Communications proposes to install a network in the Ballarat area offering pay TV and other services. Austar is apparently interested in Tasmania, although at this time East Coast Television has the regional rights.

break.para: These developments indicate the pattern of employment growth and technological advance across regional Australia which should lay to rest fears about unemployment and steam age technology in the less urbanised areas of Australia. All of this goes to confirm the words of the Managing Director of the Australian Telecommunications Users Group, Mr Allan Horsley, who told the Senate inquiry:

The industry is desperately short of people. We cannot find them. We put ads in the paper and our members are looking for people and cannot find them. Our experience has been that there is substantial demand for employment and, if as a result of any process this or just management changes in Telstra result in fewer employees, those employees will pick up work without a doubt outside. It is not overstating the case to say that demand is enormous.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question, Madam President. Given that job losses have been occurring for some years in Telstra, can the minister explain why it has suddenly become an issue now?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —It is absolutely true—
—It is not true.
—It is unfortunate that Senator Carr is so ignorant of the facts of this matter that he is not aware that, between 1991 and 1994, 25,000 jobs were lost inside Telstra.
—What about last year?
—Do not change the subject. I am just telling you the facts of the matter. I would have thought that you would understand that.

answer.para: This is a gross exercise in hypocritical double standards because, during that period of three years, unemployment was 10.3, 10.5, 11 per cent and 10.6. In other words, it was much higher than it is now. Something in the order of 850,000 to 950,000 people were unemployed, with not one squawk from the Labor Party, not one squawk from others about it, no industrial disruption.
Yet what do we have now? We have all this hypocritical hand wringing. We only have to look at the remarks of the telecommunications public sector union on this subject when they said:

break.para: It has only been after the election of a government committed to privatisation that speculation started.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Newman. The question is: at the PNG ministerial forum, did the PNG defence minister indicate an implementation program for the Defence white paper published last year? Did the ministers agree that such implementation would alter the nature of the Australian Defence cooperation program with PNG? Did Australia accede to the PNG minister's public avowals that Australia's DCP should be reviewed? Who is to conduct such a review and when will the results be known?

—Of course, our relationship with Papua New Guinea has been a longstanding one and of great importance to both countries. The defence forces of both countries have had a very strong relationship over the years and many Papua New Guinea people have been trained by the Australian Defence Force. Last week officials from both countries met, as well as did the ministers. I will obtain the details of the answer to the senator's question.

—I thank through you, Madam President, the minister for her answer to that. I wonder whether the minister would be able have answers available before program 5 in estimates, so we can follow it up there.

—As we had defence estimates for some hours yesterday, Senator, and we only got to the end of program 2, I am sure you have quite a while before you need your answer but, of course, I will get it for you.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. According to reports in the media recently, the Productivity Commission has argued that Australia Post should be required to take on more debt because its current low level of debt suppos
edly gives it an unfair advantage over the private sector.
Does the government intend to privatise all or any section of Australia Post? Would the government be prepared to direct Australia Post to borrow money it does not need? Would the government agree to abolish the uniform letter right and allow the rate for postage to set according to the cost of delivery?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —There is no intention to change the current arrangements, particularly in relation to the uniform service across Australia and, indeed, the standard postal delivery arrangements.
—Well done!
—But what is important to remember is this: on 15 November 1993, Mr Beddall, who was then the communications minister—
—Oh, here we go.
—Come on, just a moment. Don't bury your heads in the sand and somehow pretend that everything is perfect.
—Oh, dear!
—All I am telling you is—
—Order! Senator Alston, direct your remarks through the chair.
— Through the chair! Through the chair!

—Madam President, I am simply at pains to point out that the previous administration committed themselves to a review and, on 28 June this year, the Treasurer similarly announced that we would be conducting a review of Australia Post during this financial year. Mr Crean himself welcomed that and said that, as long as it was a given in any such review that the level and quality of services were maintained and that people in regional and rural areas were properly looked after, there was a capacity to expose Australia Post to more competition. That is indeed what Mr Beddall had said when he made his original announcement.

answer.para:
What ought to happen is that the fear card should not be played. You should not simply run around saying the sky is going to fall in
if you have even a review to try to introduce more competition.

I understand Senator Allison's point about the levels of debt. I have not read any Productivity Commission report to that effect. It is certainly not something that is before us at the moment. If people want to make that sort of an argument, or indeed you want to make a counter‐argument in the course of that review, then it will be perfectly open to you to do so. But I think your starting point ought to be that you should be interested in ensuring that services are not only maintained at the highest level but be delivered as efficiently as possible.

talk.start.para: —That is what you said about Telstra.

—Indeed, indeed. It is just a pity that you will not join me in trying to achieve world's best practice instead of settling for mediocrity. It is very unfortunate that some people are prepared to accept second best in this game when you do have the capacity to achieve world's best practice, when you do have the capacity to ensure that you can maintain the quality of service, lower prices, better range of products—all of the things that consumers are entitled to, all of the things that can be protected in legislation—and at the same time ensure greater efficiencies.

answer.para: As you know, Australia Post has been downsizing also, has been becoming much more commercial in recent years. I think about 55 per cent of its total revenue now comes from competitive activities and it is continuing to undergo significant growth. It can therefore do that—

talk.start.para: —In positive ownership.

—If anyone wants to put in a submission about any issues that might result in greater efficiency, you are welcome to do so. I am simply putting the proposition to you that you will have a review in due course. You will be able to explore all of those issues. In due course, Madam President, I hope that there will be an acknowledgment on all sides of the chamber, except for poor old Senator Schacht who simply wants to play the game of pure politics and clearly is not
interested and proved that. He said it himself! He told the
Australian
. It is all there.
—Through the chair.

—I do not need to say it through the chair. I am talking in the third person. He, Senator Schacht, made it very clear that he was not interested in policy outcomes; he was not interested in pure performance; he was not interested in the minutiae of administration, even though he never came within a bull's roar of it. He was simply interested in pure politics. Now I think, Madam President, that we can expect more of that from the Australian Democrats. I hope that in due course they will address the issues featured.
(Time expired)

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. If the outcome of that review that the minister has told us about is a recommendation to privatise part or the whole of Australia Post, will the government attempt to do so?

—As you probably know, one of the things around this place is that hypothetical questions do not bear on government policy, so it is simply not a question to be answered at this time. But let me say this: the issue of greater competition should not be confused with the issue of privatisation in this instance. It may well be that there will be a decision to consider increased competition in the course of that review. There may well be submissions to that effect. That is a completely separate issue. I am not aware of any suggestions of privatisation of Australia Post. Senator Allison seems to think they are floating around, but I have not read them from anyone. It seems to me that is an entirely academic proposition at the present time. If what we are talking about is greater competition, greater efficiency and better results for consumers, then I hope that that is the sort of thing that the opposition and the Australian Democrats will be supporting.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the government's decision announced in the 1996-97 budget to end the $25
million ethanol bounty scheme. What was the basis of the minister's claim that the use and production of fuel ethanol was not cost‐effective? Where exactly does the Bureau of Resource Sciences actually say, as the minister claims, that the scheme does nothing to improve the environment?

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —Let me give a bit of history for the new senator. The agreement to subsidise ethanol was a shady deal made by the Democrats and the former government to get their budget through in 1993. It was one of those decisions made without a lot of research being done—I can see former senior ministers nodding on the other side—that proved to be an abject failure. The idea was that, if we could subsidise ethanol, this would somehow replace other liquid fuels.
—Make sure it doesn't contradict what Hilly said last night.
—I will listen carefully.
—Order! Order!

—Madam President, it is very hard for me to answer with the rabble on the other side. This is a serious question and it deserves a serious answer. The idea was that if you subsidised the production of ethanol you would somehow replace liquid fuels. It goes along the theory of what happened in Brazil. In Brazil for many years, because of the absence of fossil fuels, the subsidies were given to ethanol and something like 98 per cent of all new motorcars were made to go on ethanol. Even that country found it could not continue that and the percentage of cars now made to run on ethanol in Brazil is two per cent.
—Quote the BRS.

—`Quote the BRS,' Senator Bob Collins says. The people who took up the ethanol bounty were two companies. One was CSR, which had been making ethanol at Sarina, south of Mackay, since 1927. The other one was at Manildra, where ethanol is produced as a by-product from the production of gluten from wheat. The effect of this was that from all aspects—from an environmental perspective, from a cost perspective and from many other perspectives—it could not continue to be justified. Whether or
not we had stringent budgetary measures, which we did have in this particular instance, no sensible person would continue that project.

answer.para: What was the level of the subsidy? The cost of producing ethanol was 70c per litre. The cost of producing petrol is 23c per litre. The idea was that it was to be for a limited period, at which time the industry would stand on its own feet. It was clearly obvious that the industry could not stand on its own feet and the continuance of the bounty could not be justified under any circumstances. A study was done by the Bureau of Resource Sciences, ABARE and the department. The net outcome of that study was to not continue the ethanol bounty scheme.

Let me also say that this does not mean we have walked away from ethanol as being a potential substitute down the track, but we have a long way to go. We are continuing the research program. We have kept money in the budget for the woody waste or lignocellulosic plant, as it is called. I think it is $2 million. That must be matched by the New South Wales government and by industry. But by no means have we walked away from it. It was just a silly program. It was done overnight because of a deal made between the then Labor government and the Democrats to pass the budget. It was a matter of commonsense that we had no option but to drop the bounty.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Is the minister aware of an application or expression of interest by Victoria Petroleum or any other company to carry out oil and gas exploration on Commonwealth owned land at Point Murat near Cape Range in the north-west of Western Australia in October or November of this year? Given the importance of the natural heritage values of the Cape Range National Park, the nearby Ningaloo Marine Park and the occurrence of unique underground stygofauna, or troglodytes, in the area, will the minister require an environmental impact assessment before any approval to carry out oil or gas exploration in this area is granted? If not, why not?

—I do not personally know a lot about this matter. I gather that my department has some information on it at this preliminary stage. I think the facts are pretty much as Senator Margetts outlined. It has not been designated at this stage. But, now that you have brought it to my attention, I will make some inquiries and ensure that the appropriate course of action is followed.

—My question, through you, Madam President, is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to the comments on Monday by the ABC Chairman, Mr Donald McDonald, supporting Australia Television International Pty Ltd, ATV. Minister, is it a fact that you recently wrote to the ABC board stating that ATV should be sold to commercial interests? Whose view on the ownership of ATV will prevail, yours or that of Mr McDonald's? Hasn't the statement of your views pre-empted the Mansfield inquiry process? What impact would the sale of ATV to commercial interests have on the provision of a television satellite service to the Asia-Pacific region?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —There has been a long history of difficulty with ATV in terms of raising sufficient funds from sponsorship. Indeed, we have been very supportive of it as a concept because it does make sense to try to ensure that we do have a voice in the region and I think ATV has a very important role to play, particularly where our news and current affairs are very well regarded. Nonetheless, you will recall that only towards the end of last year, I think, the then Labor government decided to allocate in the order of an additional $18 million for Australia Television over a three-year period in recognition of the fact that it still was not achieving its sponsorship target.

answer.para:
There had been a series of internal reviews of the progress of ATV and I think a recognition that it was still going to experience difficulty in identifying sponsors. Indeed, one of the major problems is that sensible market research surveys simply cannot be conducted to determine the extent of an audience, because it is not a closed subscription system—it is open—and that means we really do not
have any idea of who is watching. Against that background, it makes it very difficult for advertisers to sign up in any other than nominal amounts.

talk.start.para: —Have you seen the survey results? I have got a copy.

—What we announced on 16 July was that the government would ask the ABC to explore the possibility of delivering more efficiently the services currently being provided by Australia Television. We also announced that we would discuss with the ABC board the scope for ensuring the maintenance of ABC program content on Australia Television, particularly news and current affairs, while tendering the operation of the service to the commercial sector.
—Translated into English, that means you are going to get rid of it.

—If you do not understand English, I am afraid I cannot help you. I would have thought those words are perfectly plain. As a result of that, we will have further discussion with the ABC about how we can best progress what I think is a very sensible new approach to ensuring that we do not simply have the blinkered attitude that somehow the only way to assist a service of this nature is to simply pour more and more government dollars into it.

answer.para: The Labor Party always took the view that funding should come from outside sources. Even though it is a charter activity, it was necessary for it to garner funds from other than the taxpayer. Indeed, even when those requests were being made for additional funds and you decided to provide I think $18.6 million, you made it clear that you expected the ABC to continue to rely on sponsorship and to do its very best to expand the market audience in that regard. That is still a continuing problem. It is still an approach that we think is worth pursuing. That is why we will be having discussions with the ABC to ensure we can achieve the best possible outcome.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. So, Minister, why didn't you wait for the results of the Mansfield inquiry rather than pre-empt it?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —It was not a term of reference of the Mansfield inquiry.
—Why not?

—We do not have to ask anyone who is conducting a review to look at everything that you might think might be a passing interest. We are able to make decisions in some areas. We are also able to require advice from other areas. We are also able to seek a review in other areas. We simply made the decision in relation to ATV—
—What about political interference with the ABC?
—If we want to know all about political interference, there is only one party that we need to turn to in this chamber—the ultimate deal makers, the ultimate fixers, the ultimate heavies.

answer.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—You ought to be ashamed of yourselves about the way that Keating used to carry on. Whenever he was dissatisfied with anything, he rang them up and thumped them, didn't he. He would always kick them to death. That was the political solution to your problems—

answer.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para:
—To intimidate.
(Time expired)

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Could the minister please advise the Senate of the level of background radiation at the Ranger uranium mine in the Northern Territory? Can the minister also please assure the Senate that workers at the Ranger mine and those tourists who visit the area are in no danger?
—And is it safe to get out of the bus? And, if you didn't get out of the bus, why did you go there?
—Order!

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferris for that question and also congratulate her on asking her first question in the chamber. Senators will be aware that Ranger is one of the two operating mines under Labor's foolish three‐mine policy. From the Labor Party's point of view, the old, ridiculous story was that uranium from Ranger and Olympic Dam was good uranium but any other uranium was bad uranium. How stupid can you be?

answer.para: Senators will be aware that background levels of radiation at Ranger are insignificant in comparison with radiation levels which we all encounter every day. The total radiation exposure of project workers is monitored to ensure that radiation exposure is within international agreed limits. These are about to change from 50 millisieverts to 20 millisieverts—

Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—Obviously the Labor Party are not interested in this. The whole two‐mine policy is embarrassing to them, but they should at least be interested in the radiation levels that apply to workers and to people who visit the mine. Currently the international level is 50 millisieverts, which is going to reduce to 20 over the next five years. The average level at Ranger is five millisieverts in open working areas and one millisievert in office areas. Caution, of course, must always be exercised with exit rays of radioactive materials. It is an area that I spent ten years of my working life in. Let me say that X‐rays and radioactive materials have been a great benefit to the community at large. There are some 55 staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and 30 ERA staff involved in radiation and environmental monitoring at Ranger.

answer.para:
Visitors to Ranger face no potential hazard from radiation exposure. The total radiation exposure to members of the Senate select committee on uranium during their visit to Ranger was two to five microsieverts. Of the four members of the committee, all except one were briefed at the site. Where was Senator Margetts, the most vocal anti‐uranium advocate in the Senate? She, with the rest of the committee flew all the way to Darwin, then from Darwin to Ranger and then all the way back again and would not get out of the bus. To use her own words, as reported in the
Northern Territory News
, she felt more comfortable in the vehicle. She is reported to have said, `If there is a problem with radiation, dust is not very healthy.'

If Senator Margetts intended to sit in the bus and if she has genuine concerns, a number of questions are raised. Why did she cost the taxpayers of Australia the return trips to Darwin and Darwin to Ranger? Why did she insist that taxpayers buy her a dose meter which she then did not trust and, of course, would have been of little use in the bus, anyway. If Senator Margetts is serious, she might like to know that on her weekly flights between Canberra and Perth she receives 13 microsieverts as compared with the two to three she would have received at Ranger. She could, of course, go by road between Perth
and Canberra but to do so she would have to avoid bitumen roads and granite outcrops to avoid being exposed to radiation levels similar to or greater than she would have been exposed to at Ranger.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister for Resources and Energy please inform the parliament whether any further expenditure was incurred by Senator Margetts during that visit?

—The only other information I have is that Senator Margetts did the same thing when she went to ANSTO at Lucas Heights. One wonders why she again put the taxpayer to the trouble of doing that. I have no particular problem with Senator Margetts stating her view on nuclear power. She is the one, of course, who initiated this Senate inquiry that is going on right now. That is her prerogative. But in this particular instance she either pulled a stunt, which was at great expense to the taxpayers of Australia, or she was serious about it, in which case there is some sort of paranoia there that I cannot help her with.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to problems in investor protection for unit trusts? What is the government's view as to the most appropriate regulation of the interests of investors? Is the minister aware of the divergent views on this subject of those in the investment funds industry?

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It is a follow‐up question on ethanol after a very, shall we say, selectively misleading answer to Senator O'Brien. Minister, is it not
correct that on the issue of being competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable—and I refer you to this unsourced document you tabled in this place—is it not the fact that ABARE never conducted a current or future analysis of ethanol production; ABARE foreshadowed discussions on this type of company but never proceeded? As for robust, is it not the fact that the petroleum division of DPIE controlled the issue of production licences, not the industry, and never actively encouraged new producers outside New South Wales? As for ecologically sustainable, the evaluation at no time makes the claim that you just made that it was a complete failure. In misrepresenting the Australian production model, BRS incorrectly ascribes soil carbon flux to ethanol produced from industrial wastes from annual food crops.

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —It was very hard to hear the question being asked. I will do my best, Senator, but I can tell you that you are flogging a dead horse. You went down a loony—
—Through the chair.

—Senator Lees is flogging a dead horse. A report was put out. You are talking about the costs of production and so on. Let me say to the Senate—if that suits you—that the ethanol industry, as does any other of these industries, still gets the benefit of no excise duty and no state excises on their production. That comes to in the order of about 40c a litre. So indirectly there is a subsidy already there for these alternative forms of fuel.

answer.para: Might I also indicate that only within the last week I was approached by the Australian Conservation Foundation. Among a list of things they spoke about was the ethanol bounty. I offered them a copy of the report which they said they already had. I would have to say that they generally agreed, having reviewed the report—which is what I had at my disposal—there was no option but to go down that track of removing the bounty.

para.break: With regard to distribution, I think the ethanol contribution was 0.07 or 0.007. It was a very tiny amount, anyway, into the mix. It is a 90 per cent petrol, 10 per cent ethanol mix that occurs. Niche markets were devel oped by some independent suppliers, basically in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: —But isn't it a fact that the oil industry would not cooperate?

—Senator Lees interjects that the oil industry would not cooperate. The oil industry had no play in this whatsoever, one way or the other; it did not interest them. Even where it has been used fairly extensively, with a lot of encouragement, on the west coast of the United States, I think the total contribution, after a lot of subsidy, was about 10 per cent. It should be borne in mind that that was very much driven by the need to reduce carbon monoxide. It is not a reduction of carbon dioxide through the ethanol process; it is a reduction of carbon monoxide.

answer.para: From an environmental point of view, as Senator Lees should know, because of the lead policies introduced in Australia, carbon monoxide levels have in fact reduced in this country. So carbon monoxide levels, from a pollutant point of view, are actually going down in Australia, not up.

The other area where it can be important if you have got high levels of carbon monoxide is in very cold climates. I think that climatic point of view is referred to in the report. I am not sure, but I know that is the advice that I have got.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of follow‐up questions, Madam President. Minister, this document has been refuted page by page by the industry. I ask: have you got a copy of that? I am particularly interested to know why this was unsourced, why you have not been able to include in the document you released the information on which you base this. As far as subsidies are concerned, is it not a fact that over $800 million is going to the diesel fuel rebate alone? This industry was never meant to be a competitive industry before the year 2000. Indeed, it was given seed funding and they were looking at the year 2000 before they would be able to go on their own. The final part of my question is: is it not a fact that they saw the year 2000 as being the time by which they would no longer need to have the bounty?

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —My understanding is that the initial program was a three‐year program. The industry certainly asked for it to be extended to the year 2000; that is quite correct. All the evaluations we have done were done quite independently—by BRS, ABARE and the department. To say that the department controlled it is an absolute nonsense.

answer.para:
Let me repeat: it does not mean we are turning our back on alternative fuels. I mentioned before that there is an amount of money still set aside in the budget for the lignocellulosics plant, which is woody waste. Also, the Energy Research and Development Corporation has an amount set aside for continuing research into this process. Finally, even in today's paper, which is what sparked off these questions, it is recognised that if you use crops to make ethanol, you are going to contribute to greenhouse gas emissions.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. After the minister gagged Aviation Safety Authority officials during the estimates hearings last night and prevented them from answering any questions relating to the unprecedented political direction of the minister for transport to overturn the decision of the authority to require the fitting of automatically activating emergency locator beacons, the minister said that the government had issued this direction on `the best advice'. He went on to say that `the government was conscious of the consequences of the decision'. Can the minister now advise the Senate what was, to quote him, `the best advice' that the minister for transport used to take this unprecedented action in overturning a safety authority decision on equipment to be installed in Australian aircraft? —In the course of last night's proceedings, after Senator Collins had made a fool of himself by suggesting that somehow you could ask officials about the level of morale in the department in relation to decisions, I was asked, with a preface, `I
accept that you won't have any first‐hand knowledge on this issue, but could you indicate the government's general approach'. I said that without knowing the merits of the decision, I would assume—
—What?

—Do you want the answer or not? I would assume that the government had access to the best advice, that it would have made the decision conscious of all the relevant factors, that it would not have been an arbitrary or capricious decision and that we therefore would have ensured that we had access to all the necessary information. All I am saying to you is that those are approaches that one would expect of good government. I am quite happy to ask Mr Sharp to provide you with as much as he possibly can in terms of the information that was taken into account in the making of that decision. But I am sure you understand now, as you understood then, that I did not have any personal knowledge of the issue. I therefore did not have access to the advice.
—Oh, yes!

—Of course. I was making it plain to you last night that all I could do was assume, as one would normally assume, and I think you were nodding vigorously at the end of that exchange, that that is indeed the best approach to adopt. You did not pursue the matter further for that reason. I say to you again that in making this decision—
—Senator Alston, your answer should not be addressed directly to the questioner.
—It is surprising, Madam President, that the other side did not take a point of order. The fact is—
—I was impeccable, Dick.

—Well, you might have been impeccable to that extent but Senator Collins certainly was not impeccable in pursuing the matter last night. He did accept that there were principles of good government and good decision making that did involve having access to all the necessary facts and information. That includes the advice that is
available to the minister. Naturally, I will invite the minister to respond in the most helpful way possible.

—Following that interesting answer from Senator Alston, is Senator Alston aware that his assumption that he has just told us about was sadly flawed and that the reason the minister for transport took what we were advised last night was an unprecedented action in politically directing the authority in respect of overturning a decision on safety equipment on aircraft was in fact a payment for some help that was given to the now government during the election campaign in some newsletters that were published, which I will canvass at a future time. —I am aware that Senator Collins did read into the
Hansard
record before seeking to table or incorporate it a letter which I think was dated 5 May 1995—
—No, that has nothing to do with this question.

—I thought it had. Senator Collins I thought was suggesting that a decision was taken for reasons that were based on presentations made to the minister. If that is not so, of course I will disregard it. I simply say this, Madam President: whatever decision Mr Sharp made, he was not required to have access only to the advice that you think he should have taken into account.
—What!
—He was entitled to take into account all of the necessary areas of advice that are available to him, and he makes that judgment as best he can.
—About what equipment is fitted to aircraft?

—He does not have to take a decision based on what you think is the appropriate advice. He makes the decision on advice that appeals to him.
(Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, a recent article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
reported that the Commonwealth Bank plans to give about $100 million of its shares to employees over the next three years under proposed changes to the share staff scheme announced in the federal budget. Therefore, can you outline how employees will benefit from the budget proposal for the taxation of employees' share plans.

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for his question. It is a subject in which he has long had a keen interest.
—Oh!
—He has. It is a bit different from the other side of politics. Yes, I did notice the article to which Senator McGauran referred. It was also contained in other papers.

answer.para: It is very pleasing to note that, not one month after the budget announcement, the business community is endorsing and acting on the government's policies to the possible benefit of many, many thousands of employees. I understand, as Senator McGauran has intimated, that the Commonwealth Bank is planning three employee share plans, one of which will be offered to most of the bank's 36,000 full‐time and part-time staff. Those plans have to be approved, I understand, by shareholders at the annual general meeting next month.

The government announced in the budget its commitment to its election promise to provide more generous tax treatment for employees' share schemes, which was, of course, yet another promise delivered in full to the benefit of employees from the factory floor to the executive level. That is on top of the other election promises that were delivered in full and on time, of course: the family tax initiative, the private health insurance initiative, the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business, the reduction in provisional tax uplift factor and other things that will benefit small business and average Australians.

break.para: Now, not more than a month after the budget, a major business house, we see, is announcing plans which are tailored to take advantage of our proposal. We want to see and to encourage further participation in employees' share schemes and to encourage greater voluntary saving. We want to see more employees owning shares in their employers' businesses through employees' share schemes because through those schemes we can promote greater industrial harmony and help break down the barriers between management and employees.

Employees' share schemes have a very important and significant role in this case. That is why we announced in the budget that, from 1 July 1996, the value of shares or rights that may be tax exempt under qualifying employees' schemes will be doubled from $500 to $1,000 per employee per year. On top of that, from 1 July this year, the government will ease the employee participation conditions for qualifying employees' share schemes from 75 per cent of permanent employees to two-thirds of permanent employees for shares under the tax deferral concession and for shares and rights under the exemption concession. That will make it much easier for employees' share schemes to meet the participation conditions with the flow-on effect of concessional tax treatment.

Legislation will be introduced into the parliament in the next few weeks to give effect to those proposals, which I must say are in quite stark contrast to the Labor Party's policies in relation to this area. The Senate will recall that in the 1994 budget Labor unveiled a plan to impose fringe benefits tax on those schemes. Labor's 1994 budget announcement would have thrown employees' share schemes pretty well out the window overnight and it was clear to everybody but the then Treasurer, Mr Willis, that the plan would spell the death knell of those schemes, in stark contrast to ours.
(Time expired)

question.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

question.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —I wish to add to an answer that I gave to the Senate on Monday when I indicated that, in respect of suggestions of a $400 million windfall:

question.para: If you look at the dividend figure of $1.368 billion, you find that is only about $74 million more than the implicit figure which we had budgeted for. In other words, there is a very minor increase.

I did have discussions with the Treasurer yesterday morning, and he indicated that he was having work done in his office. This morning my attention has been drawn to the fact that yesterday, after question time in the House of Representatives, Mr Costello indicated that that work had demonstrated that the special dividend in respect of 1996‐97 had not been taken into account by the Treasury in assessing the extent of the difference between the budget estimate and the actual announced dividend. What follows from that, of course, is that there is no windfall of anything of the dimensions of $400 million—not only as indicated by the Australian Democrats, but as supported by Kim Beazley. In fact, on those figures, there is indeed a shortfall.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President. I rise to speak briefly on the issues that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) has mentioned on the personal level. I will also, probably like a number of senators, be rising on the substantive issue to deal with the issues of his answer to the question from Senator Ferris.

speech.para: The first point I would like to make is that the minister has in effect misled the Senate. First of all, he has said that I insisted that the committee pay for a radiation dose meter. I do not know where the minister got that information, but it is incorrect, so he is in effect misleading the Senate.

break.para: What in fact I did—and Senator Parer obviously did not talk about the internals of a private meeting—was ask for information to enable me to hire a dose meter for the trip to the Northern Territory. The outcome of the discussion with the committee was that I was advised that that would be organised.

talk.start.para: —The company would have given you one up there.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I believe that when a personal explanation is being given it ought to be heard without interjection.
—You are correct. Senator Margetts.

—I thank the Senate. In the end, the committee secretariat said that they were offered the use of two—as I was advised originally—dose meters. In fact, the Australian Radiation Laboratory offered to let us borrow two TLD monitor film badges. They were not dose meters.

break.para: The minister said I could have known that there was a high level of radiation because I did not trust the technology. Once again, Senator Parer has misled the Senate because a film badge will not give you a reading. It might change colour if you are in a very high level of radiation, but it does not give you a reading in a particular location; you have to have it analysed later.
We were going to four different uranium mine sites. Out of curiosity, I thought I would wear the dose meter during the visits to the mine sites and have it analysed later.
The minister has used this place to defame me on the basis of taking the interest and the work that I have done—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Personal explanations—and, indeed, the opposition has made this point with me from time to time—are simply to set the record straight, and are not an opportunity to make allegations against other people, for example, by someone saying that a minister has defamed her.

—Order! With personal explanations there can be no debate. I have been listening to Senator Margetts
carefully. I do not think she has transgressed that area yet.

—Let me point out another area where the minister has misled the Senate in this instance. The minister said that I did the same thing at Lucas Heights. When the committee went to Lucas Heights we were not offered dose meters. Other people on the staff had them. Most of them turned them off. Only one person, one staff member, had their dose meter on—it actually was one that gave readings. That person stayed back where I was when the committee was being shown radioactive waste repositories. So there was no instance where I was wearing a radioactive dose meter at Lucas Heights. They were not offered. However, we were not permitted by the Queensland government to go to the Esk facility unless we were wearing a radioactive dose meter.

break.para: I think that the minister certainly owes me an apology. The information that he has used was based on a Northern Territory newspaper article. I was contacted by the—

talk.start.para: —Order! I think you are starting to debate the issue.
—No, I am sorry.
—I am sorry, you are. You may continue, but do not debate the issue. You are making a personal explanation.

—Mr Deputy President, during the debate the minister quoted from an article in the Northern Territory press. I am explaining what is also incorrect in that article. The journalist contacted me and said, `I hear you also didn't get out of the bus in your sightseeing at Kakadu.' He was fishing. The delegation did not do any sightseeing on that trip. Therefore, basically, the journalist was trying to find out whether or not I had got out at Kakadu.

break.para:
During his statement today the minister also made comments about what information is available on Ranger workers. That is more the substantive issue. I believe that I am owed an apology because the information is not correct. It is true that in the circumstances of a dusty mine environment at the Ranger uranium mine, I chose to stay in the bus because
I felt more comfortable out of the dust of a uranium mine. I think that is a reasonable thing to do. There is a difference between ingested radiation and gamma radiation. I believe it is reasonable for me not to be forced to breathe in dust from a uranium mine on such an inquiry.

There are very few people who do more work on the issue of radiation and radiation policy in this chamber than I do. So if there is any suggestion that I am wasting taxpayer's money, the minister ought to find out the facts. I will be seeking leave to take note of the substantive issues.

speech.speaker: Lees, Sen Meg

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked by Senator Lees and Senator O'Brien today, relating to the cessation of the ethanol bounty scheme.

As the Minister for Resources and Energy said, the horse is dead. If it is, it is thanks to the minister who I presume has deliberately pursued a policy of removing what I think many in the oil industry see as a threat.

I will come back to the substantive matter and deal initially with the unsourced document that was tabled in this place a few weeks ago. I ask the minister: firstly, why is it unsourced? I think it is most unusual for a document to be put down in this place in this way. Perhaps the back page is missing. I have no bibliography, no attachments, to tell me what documentation you used to put this together. There is no indication of which scientific materials, what research papers, were used and which departments were involved. If you read through the body of it, you find that several departments are mentioned.

I begin by calling on the minister to please put before this chamber all the documents he used to put together this unsourced document. If we are not able to get them, shall we say, easily and, hopefully, happily minister, we will probably have to go through the process
of a return to order to make sure that we can find our way through the maze to establish how on earth you came to many of the very strange conclusions.

I will just deal very briefly with a few of the conclusions. On the question of whether or not this industry is competitive, I would argue that it was never intended that the industry would be up and running in the two years that it has had the bounty scheme. Indeed it was given seed funding to enable it to begin to get going, to begin to prove that it was going to be in the longer term economically viable and that it could be competitive.

I can find no evidence that ABARE ever conducted a current or future analysis of ethanol production in Australia. ABARE foreshadowed discussions of this kind with Manildra, the company—in particular, with some financial personnel from the company—but never actually proceeded with this review. The model that it has used incorrectly relied on Brazilian data and, I believe, some United States data. So in conducting its overall analysis, ABARE further compounds its error by concentrating on Brazil and US models, which are not representative of ethanol production in Australia.

We then come to the question of a robust industry. As I said in my question, the petroleum division of DPIE controlled the issue of production losses. There was no chance for the industry to build up to the point where we really could begin to talk about whether or not it was robust. It seems that outside of New South Wales there was no active encouragement for expansion.

The refusal of large foreign owned oil companies to distribute and market fuel ethanol initially imposed severe limits on the capacity of producers to take up the bounty allocation in these first two years of the scheme. Despite this policy of non-cooperation adopted by the major oil companies, ethanol producers succeeded in establishing a steadily expanding market in New South Wales—a steadily expanding market for fuel ethanol with the cooperation of the independent oil companies who were prepared to look at a new product and to take what
they saw as a risk. But it turned out to be quite profitable for them. I have been reliably informed that, as fast as the ethanol could be produced, it was able to be marketed through independent oil companies.

Advice from one ethanol producer that their company would, with the benefit of the bounty, produce ethanol by 2000 without any further need for support was totally ignored. Indeed, nowhere in this document do you find that any real opportunity has been given for the companies, particularly Manildra, to put their point of view or to in any way refute some of the very questionable evidence that has been put before us.

On the question of ecological sustainability, the evaluation that we have before us at no time actually makes the claim that the scheme was a complete failure, as the minister said on a couple of occasions. In misrepresenting the Australian production model, BRS incorrectly ascribes soil carbon flux to ethanol produced from industrial wastes from annual food crops. BRS acknowledged international research on the benefits of ethanol in relation to emissions of primary vehicle resource pollutants, but also identified complexities in determining the level of any evaporative emissions associated with ethanol fuel blends.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Panizza, Sen John

talk.start.para: —I would like to enter this ethanol debate for a very short period, because it is something that I have had experience with in the past. I have had experience of trying to set up a plant to produce ethanol on farm. In the United States from around 1965 to 1970 there was the big push for ethanol production with the so-called world oil crisis.

speech.para:
However, you have to face realities. Ethanol production was first tried in Australia, somewhat successfully, during World War II because there was no other alternative. Cost was not a consideration because, if fuel was required, it had to be manufactured and it had to be got hold of somehow. It was tried with reasonable success. But we do not know for certain because that cost was not compared with other fuels. At the time gas producers seemed to have been far more efficient in
producing for the average smaller vehicle, although gas producers were pretty useless when it came to heavy vehicles.

The next upsurge in the idea of producing ethanol as an alternative fuel came in about 1969 in Australia. It was tried at a time when the world overproduction of wheat was on and when Australia, for a very short time, had wheat quotas. There were a few experimental plants in Australia. But, even with wheat in those days of 1969-70 at around $50 a tonne, it was not viable to produce ethanol and use it successfully even with the rising world prices of oil.

During that time I personally got quotes from the United States to get a plant out in order to erect on the farm and produce ethanol. But when you worked out that, with the average farm production unit the United States supplied at the time, it would take virtually two or three years to manufacture ethanol that you would use in one year; the cost factor was blown out as well as not being able to get enough production. Then, of course, wheat prices took a big jump in 1973-74 and ethanol was put on the backburner again.

We have the case here, as has come out today, where, in order to get last year's budget through, some toing-and-froing went on with the Democrats and a certain amount was inserted into the budget to have a look at the ethanol situation again. Unfortunately, economics has proven that both ethanol and the cost of production of ethanol at the present moment cannot compete with other fuels. Furthermore, as Senator Margetts would know, the Metropolitan Transport Trust in Perth—Metrobus or whatever they call it—has had a couple of diesel buses converted to run on ethanol running around for quite some time. Although the operation has been rather successful, unfortunately, the economics has not. QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE SENATOR LEES—17 SEPTEMBER 1996
Hospital Funding

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. The cuts in the budget for public hospital funding, some $312 million across all States, are apparently
there because the States have been cost shifting. Could you please explain what has been happening with regard to cost shifting? What have the States been doing? Which States have been doing what? How are you going to spread those $312 million in cuts over four years across the States? Finally, given the enormous problems facing our public hospital system, is your government prepared to reconsider this move and, in particular, are you prepared to consider allocating the one per cent increase in the Medicare levy for high income earners directly into the public hospital system?

Minister, when you are seeking further details from the Minister for Health, could you please ask if he will again reconsider this move, considering the pressure that the public hospital system is under. Last June—you are quite right—all States agreed to stop cost shifting, but they are insisting that they have stopped cost shifting. So can you ask the Minister what evidence he has of where the cost shifting is occurring, and who is doing what? My final question is: could you please again check whether he is prepared to look at allocating the increase in the Medicare levy directly into the state public hospital system?

Senator Lees asked several questions about the Budget measure addressing cost shifting under the Medicare program. I indicated that I would follow up on the details of this matter. I now have the relevant information.
There has been no cut in the Budget to hospital funding. The Forward Estimates show that Hospital Financing Grants have been maintained in their entirety across the four years of the estimate.

No efficiency dividend has been applied to Hospital Financing Grants, despite the significant improvements in efficiency in public hospitals in recent years. The Commonwealth would have been justified in asking the States for a share of these savings, but chose not to do so.

The cost shifting measure is not a cut to hospital funding. This measure is an acknowledgment that the Commonwealth is recouping some of the money being taken out of the Medicare system by the States, contrary to the commitment given at the April 1995 meeting of Health Ministers. Given that the amount being cost-shifted is greater than the amount being recouped, it could be said that hospital funding has actually been increased.
Cost-shifting is still going on—for example, one Melbourne hospital has 62 privatised out-patient services, some of which have been established very recently.

States cost-shift at different levels—at this point we do not have precise data. Estimates are based on Health Insurance Commission data, and the Department of Health is confident that over the coming months very exact figures can be devel
oped. The cost-shifting measure recoups costs in proportion to the amounts by which States cost-shift.

The Government has already recognised the problems of public hospitals by its decision not to apply an efficiency dividend to Hospital Financing Grants. Difficulties the hospitals experience are related to the decisions made by State Governments about their hospital funding.

The Minister for Health has advised me that no State has stopped cost-shifting, and substantial evidence from medical practitioners who are being pressured to change the way they treat patients in casualty in public hospitals, and also to arrange pre- and post-operative work-ups away from hospitals gives a clear indication that the practice continues, in contravention of the Medicare Agreements.

The purpose of this bill is to introduce amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992, the Agricultural and Chemicals Code Act 1994, the Fisheries Management Act 1991, the Farm Household Support Act 1992, the Imported Food Control Act 1992 and the Quarantine Act 1908.
The bill further repeals the following inoperative acts:
Apple and Pear Export Underwriting Act 1981
Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Act 1977
Coal Production (War‐time) Act Repeal Act 1948
Dairy Industry Stabilisation Act 1977
Dairy Industry Stabilisation Levy Act 1977
Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Act 1982
Fishing Industry Act 1956
Fishing Industry Research Act 1969
Fishing Industry Research and Development Act 1987
International Sugar Agreement act 1978
Rural industries research act 1985
Wheat Tax Act 1957
Wheat Tax Act 1979
Wheat Tax (Permit) Act 1984
Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Act 1984

The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 will ensure that the national registration authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals (NRA) is required to comply with the policy directions of the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand. This is in accordance with the principle of the Commonwealth, state, and territory governments being equal partners in setting the policy direction of the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

A number of the other proposed amendments are collectively concerned with the department of primary industries and energy's management of chemicals subject to import and export restrictions under international obligations such as the prior informed consent procedures. The obtaining of information about chemical products from the NRA is a factor in that management. The proposed amendments will not place any additional reporting burden on the chemical industry as the necessary information is already required to be provided to the NRA.

Provision is also proposed for the NRA to be able to impose a fee for the issuing of certificates of export. Those certificates relate to requests from the chemical industry or importing countries to establish the bona fides of a particular chemical product following evaluation of the product by the NRA. Appeal provisions to the administrative appeals tribunal will be available to aggrieved applicants in the event of the NRA's refusal to issue a certificate.

The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994 clarify the application of the compensation provisions under part 3 of the code. Those provisions apply when certain information is provided on request to the NRA as part of the review of existing agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The related transitional provisions have also been clarified.

It is also proposed to introduce provisions to streamline the issuing of national notices under the agvet codes. This will enable the NRA to issue one national notice rather than separate notices for each jurisdiction, and represents improved efficiency for the NRA.

The amendment to the Fisheries Management Act 1991 will provide that where there is an acquisition of property within the meaning of paragraph 31 of section 51 of the constitution, reasonable compensation or compensation as determined by the federal court, is payable.

The Farm Household Support Act 1992 is being amended to ensure that the drought relief payment is payable to eligible farmers only within the period specified on the drought exceptional circumstances certificate. This will ensure that drought relief payments are used by eligible farmers to meet their basic living expenses only during those periods of extreme drought.
The amendments to reinsert drought relief payment to section 43(1) are to correct previous consequential amendments which erroneously omitted drought relief payment from this section.
The Farm Household Support Act 1992 is also being amended to exempt from the drought relief payment income test any proceeds from the forced disposal of livestock.
The amendment will correct an anomaly in the existing legislation governing the payment of drought relief payment.

At present, for the purposes of the drought relief payment, if a farmer is forced to dispose of livestock due to extreme drought, the proceeds from the forced sale are treated as income for the period in which they are received.

This means the proceeds are assessed under the income test for the drought relief payment. The effect of this treatment is that the farmer may be excluded from assistance under the drought relief payment or have his or her entitlement reduced.
Following this amendment all proceeds from the forced disposal of livestock will be excluded from the income test for the purpose of the drought relief payment.

The purpose of the amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 is to allow persons other than officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to be appointed as authorised officers.
The amendment will allow quarantine officers of the various state and territory departments of agriculture to be involved in the inspection of food imported into Australia.
AQIS anticipates a more effective and efficient service to clients as a consequence of the amendment as it minimises, where possible, the duplication of inspection activities.

The purpose of the amendment of the Quarantine Act 1908 is to provide for a system which allows for the issue of penalty notices, which are better known as on‐the‐spot fines, to persons alleged to have breached Australia's Quarantine Act or
regulations by failing to declare, or intentionally incorrectly declaring, goods of quarantine concern when entering australia. Initially the system will be operated at all Australia's international airports.
The system will allow the imposition of a penalty for relatively minor offences which, under existing arrangements, would not normally be able to be pursued through the courts.

The existence of the system will be widely advertised and is expected to increase compliance with Australia's quarantine requirements and thus minimise the risk to australia's agricultural industries.
