speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —This is the first opportunity, apart from by way of personal explanation, I have had to deal with the issues that were brought up during question time today in relation to the answer from the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, to the question by Senator Ferris. The issues that were raised by way of a question on the radiation levels at Ranger uranium mine were in fact an effort to have a cheap shot and a bit of a laugh at my expense. It is interesting. As I pointed out during my explanation, the minister does owe me apologies and I will be expecting to receive those apologies in relation to the incorrect information he has given to the Senate.

speech.para: But there is some further information that is necessary to add to this. The workers at Ranger uranium mine—it was Ranger that was mentioned—do not have an accurate record of how much radiation they receive. The method currently being used at Ranger tends to be an average method. There is equipment in various locations throughout the mine which measure radiation.

break.para: But, for cost reasons, and this was given as evidence to the inquiry, the Ranger uranium mine no longer requires all its workers in the mine to wear even the film badges that I wore to the uranium mine during the recent hearings and visits. Only those people who are virtually constantly working in restricted areas are required to wear them. In areas that are constantly dusty there are other requirements, which include breathing apparatus, and I believe there are other hazardous areas within the mine and the mill which are not necessarily related only to radiation.

But statements about the doses that individual workers are subject to are made now on averages only. This can mean that, if there is an average of five, some people may be getting eight or nine and some people may be getting two. Unfortunately most individual workers will not have an accurate record of the doses of radiation they have received while working in the mines.

I do not think there are many people more aware than me of the fact that being a politician is an unhealthy lifestyle. I am also aware that various forms of radiation occur from granite buildings. I am aware of the fact that the natural environment is an area where there is naturally occurring radiation. I do not tend to spend hours and hours on top of granite outcrops, but I am working in a building which is made of various sorts of emitters of radiation; I am aware of that.

I am also aware of the fact that flying in aircraft, which I do not particularly like doing, is not a particularly healthy thing to do. There are of course levels of radiation which occur from that. In fact, I was interested in finding out just how unhealthy this lifestyle is. My initial inquiries about a year ago were to find out whether or not I could wear a cumulative dose meter for the whole of the year and get it checked from time to time to find out how unhealthy this lifestyle is.

Senator Parer, during the course of today's very badly informed answer to Senator Ferris, mentioned that I refused to get out of the bus. Yes; in the bottom of the pit of Ranger 1 ore body, where there was still workings going on, I did not actually get out of the bus, that
is true. At other areas of the mine site and around the mill, including the artificial wetlands to try to leach out the radiation, it is true that I did not get out of the bus; I made a choice. We had had those issues explained. I had been with the rest of the committee members and taking copious notes during the briefings that we were given by the mine staff.

I think a number of people would agree with me that I was taking what is known as basic radiological protection measures at the bottom of the pit. The protection measures were in relation to the possible inhalation or ingestion of small particles of dust. The minister seemed not to understand the difference between gamma rays and alpha emitters. I understand that the actual background radiation in some of those areas that may have been dusty may not necessarily have been high. But, in the vicinity of a uranium mine, of course you are going to get uranium dust. You also may get remnants of thorium‐234, or thorium‐230 or radium‐226.

There is a lot of dust around a mine, and I think it is eminently sensible for anybody not to deliberately breathe in that dust if they have a choice; that is, they can see what the bottom of the pit, the mine and the mill look like and they have had that explained to them, and they choose not to get out of the bus for three minutes at the bottom of the pit. I do not see why that was considered to be such an extraordinary thing.

We also visited Rum Jungle. Perhaps I did a less sensible thing at Rum Jungle, where there is no dust from a current mine. Of course, this mine was used long ago but it is still in a disgraceful condition. Much of the radiation from almost any mine remains at the mine site in the form of waste. The thorium‐234, thorium‐230 and radium‐226 are still there. Of course, when they mine for uranium they try to retrieve a large portion of the uranium, but the larger portion of the radiation remains at the mine site.

It is also true that other areas within that region have high levels of recorded radiation. It is also true that water courses within that region have been contaminated. The fact that the level of contamination in the water may
be similar to the level of radiation you might read from a granite outcrop does not necessarily accord. You do not drink granite outcrops, but people are expected to drink water. If the outcomes of mining or milling activities are that radiation gets into the water system, then comparing it, for instance, to background radiation of granite rock outcrops is immaterial.

As I say, you do not drink large granite rocks in general, but people are being expected to drink water which may be contaminated. Whether it is ground water through artificial wetlands, in the end that water system will be contaminated by radiation. If you create artificial wetlands, then the soil itself is being deliberately contaminated by radiation by being some sort of filter to try to stop all of that radiation going through into the ground water system. We are talking about wetlands here.

During our inquiries we did look at Nabarlek. Once again, at Nabarlek there is waste rock, there is waste in the pit, but the majority of radiation is still there. I think it is extremely important that people do have accurate information about the implications for workers. We are adjusting them down all the time.

It is also important to understand that, during the inquiry in Darwin, the Northern Territory government said if only a very careful check of radiation at Ranger had have been done and that, if the check that was done had not been done, the average radiation levels would have been shown to be a lot lower. I thought that was interesting. Why would people coming to check the radiation levels have a much higher reading? I asked whether those people were wearing accurate dose meters all the time and the answer was yes, they were. So why did the people who came to check the mine end up with much higher readings? The answer given was, `Senator, that's because they must have been staying in restricted areas much longer than the average worker.' I find that amazing.

In visiting the four uranium mines, I thought it would be a useful piece of personal information to find out, even by staying in the bus, what level of exposure there was from
walking on Nabarlek, talking at the mine site at Ranger—we only flew over the site for Jabiluka—and visiting the appalling mess of Rum Jungle and Rum Jungle South. During those activities, yes, I did have with me a film badge, although I would have liked to have had a dose meter that showed me readings.
(Time expired)

question.speaker: Woodley, Sen John

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 31 May 1996:

question.para: (1) Is it the case that the use of bullbars on cars and other vehicles is illegal under Federal Australian Design Rule 42.9.1.1, or any other regulation or legislation.
(2) Are the restrictions on the use of bullbars being enforced by the State Governments.
(3) How many fatalities in Australia are assessed as being predominantly due to the presence of bullbars.
(4) Are there any proposals currently under consideration to develop or enforce tighter restrictions on the use of bullbars.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Australian Design Rule 42 does not specifically proscribe bullbars, but clause 42.9.1.1 seeks to prohibit external and internal projections which are not technically essential to the vehicle. The issue of whether or not a bullbar is technically essential hinges on the consideration of the environment in which the vehicle operates. Country drivers argue strongly that a bullbar is essential for rural operations.

A more recent issue is the effect that bullbars may have on the crash performance of vehicles required to comply with Australian Design Rule 69/00—Full Frontal Impact Occupant Protection. The fitting of bullbars to vehicles after they have been sold to the market could compromise compliance with this rule. Some vehicle manufacturers have developed bullbar designs which do not adversely affect the crash performance of vehicles.

The Australian Design Rules apply to the design and construction of vehicles when first supplied to the market in Australia. Regulation of the use of vehicles and associated equipment when they are in service is the responsibility of the States and Territories. Generally they require on‐going compliance with the Australian Design Rules which applied when the vehicle was manufactured, but can
make exceptions as outlined in the answer to part 2 of this question.

(2) The State Governments have permitted the use of bullbars, and in fact Clause 96(8) of the Victorian Road Safety Act 1986 reads `Regulations made under this Act must not (a) prohibit the fitting of bullbars to motor vehicles'.

(3) The Federal Office of Road Safety has reviewed the Fatality File for 1992 which shows that of the 350 pedestrian fatalities in that year, 38 crashes involved vehicles fitted with bullbars. Of these 38 crashes, there were 3 passenger cars, 12 off‐road vehicles, 4 utilities and 19 trucks. 101 vehicles were not fitted with bullbars and there were 173 vehicles for which the accident report did not record the presence or absence of bullbars.

It is not possible with the available data to determine whether the presence of bullbars in these crashes was the predominant cause of fatalities. Pedestrian fatalities are the result of a complex set of factors and the relative contribution of each is difficult to determine.

(4) A working group comprising Government authorities, industry representatives, road user groups and researchers, is working towards resolving the long standing debate over the effect of bullbars on pedestrians, and the more recent concerns over their effect on crash performance of modern vehicles.
There are design issues which need to be addressed. Some bullbars are unduly aggressive to pedestrians, with sharp edges and small diameter tubing.

The bullbar working group is considering a proposal to develop an Australian Standard for the design and mounting of bullbars. The aim is to ensure that bullbars will be designed to minimise injury to pedestrians by attending to details such as the shape and projection of the bullbar as well as incorporating energy absorbing padding and addressing concerns regarding any adverse effects of the crash performance of the vehicle.
